DataElement.preferredName: Laboratory Procedure Discover New Malignant Cell Origin Performance New Malignant Cell Origin Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The indicator that describes whether or not a laboratory procedure was performed to determine the new malignancy cell of origin.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting._See for the first time; identify._Having no previous example or precedent or parallel; of a kind not seen before._Cells of, or derived from, a malignant tumor._The place where something begins or comes from in either the sense of a physical location or a metaphysical source._An action that is carried out or accomplished.

PermissibleValues.value: The only new malignancy in this reporting period was "other skin malignancy(basal cell, squamous)"

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not otherwise specified.: 1. An organ and the enveloping membrane of the body; includes, in addition to the epidermis and dermis, all of the derivatives of the epidermis, e.g., hairs, nails, sudoriferous and sebaceous glands, and mammary glands. Subdivisions of the skin surround various body parts; as a whole, the skin constitutes the external surface of the body. 2. The rind, capsule, or covering of any body or part.: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
An organ that constitutes the external surface of the body. It consists of the epidermis, dermis, and skin appendages.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.
